hints: The closest planet to the Sun.
It has no moons.
Its day is longer than its year.
The second planet from the Sun.
Its thick atmosphere causes a runaway greenhouse effect.
It rotates in the opposite direction of most other planets.
The only planet known to harbor life.
The third planet from the Sun.
Home to the largest ocean, the Pacific.
Known as the Red Planet.
Home to the largest volcano in the Solar System, Olympus Mons.
It has two small moons, Phobos and Deimos.
The largest planet in the Solar System.
Known for its Great Red Spot.
It has four large Galilean moons.
The sixth planet from the Sun.
Famous for its prominent ring system.
Its largest moon is Titan.
An ice giant with a faint ring system.
It rotates on its side.
The seventh planet from the Sun.
The eighth and farthest planet from the Sun.
Known for its deep blue color.
Its largest moon is Triton.
A dwarf planet in the Kuiper Belt.
Once considered the ninth planet.
It has a heart-shaped feature on its surface.
The star at the center of our Solar System.
It accounts for over 99 percent of the Solar System's mass.
Its energy is produced by nuclear fusion.
Earth's only natural satellite.
Its phases are caused by its orbit around Earth.
It is responsible for tides on Earth.
A massive system of stars, gas, and dust.
Our home is within the Milky Way one.
Can be spiral, elliptical, or irregular.
A cloud of interstellar gas and dust.
Often called a 'stellar nursery' where new stars are born.
The Orion one is a famous example.
An extremely luminous active galactic nucleus.
Powered by a supermassive black hole.
The most distant objects we can observe.
A highly magnetized, rotating neutron star.
It emits beams of electromagnetic radiation.
Discovered by Jocelyn Bell Burnell.
A region of spacetime with gravity so strong nothing can escape.
Its boundary is called the event horizon.
Sagittarius A* is one at the center of our galaxy.
The powerful and luminous explosion of a star.
It marks the end of a massive star's life.
Can result in a neutron star or a black hole.
A small icy body that orbits the Sun.
Develops a glowing 'tail' when it gets close to the Sun.
Halley's one is famous for its 76-year orbit.
A rocky body in space, smaller than a planet.
Most of them are found in a belt between Mars and Jupiter.
The Chicxulub one is thought to have caused the dinosaur extinction.
The streak of light seen when a space rock enters the atmosphere.
Often called a 'shooting star'.
Occurs during a meteor shower.
An instrument used to observe distant objects.
Can be optical, radio, or infrared.
The Hubble is a famous example.
A building with a powerful instrument for viewing space.
Often located on high mountains to avoid light pollution.
Examples include Mauna Kea and the Palomar one.
An object placed in orbit around a celestial body.
Can be natural, like the Moon, or artificial.
The first one was Sputnik 1.
A vehicle propelled by a reaction engine.
Used to launch spacecraft into orbit.
The Saturn V was used for the Apollo missions.
A famous space telescope.
Named after astronomer Edwin Hubble.
It has provided stunning images of distant galaxies.
A pair of space probes launched in the 1970s.
They are currently in interstellar space.
They carry a 'golden record' for extraterrestrial life.
A space probe that studied Saturn and its moons.
It ended its mission by plunging into Saturn's atmosphere.
Named after an Italian-French astronomer.
A group of stars forming a pattern.
Often named after mythological figures or animals.
Orion and Ursa Major are well-known examples.
A belt of constellations through which the Sun, Moon, and planets move.
Includes twelve signs, like Aries and Libra.
It is a concept in both astronomy and astrology.
A prominent constellation in the winter sky.
Also known as 'The Hunter'.
Contains the stars Betelgeuse and Rigel.
A person trained to travel in a spacecraft.
Neil Armstrong was the first to walk on the Moon.
Their Russian equivalent is a cosmonaut.
A large spacecraft that orbits the Earth.
Serves as a long-term habitat for astronauts.
The ISS is an example.
A unit of distance used in astronomy.
The distance light travels in one year.
It is about 9.46 trillion kilometers.
The force that attracts two bodies with mass.
It holds planets in orbit around the Sun.
Described by Newton and refined by Einstein.
The path of a celestial body around another.
It is a result of gravity.
Can be circular or elliptical.
The leading theory for the origin of the universe.
It describes the universe expanding from a hot, dense state.
The universe is still expanding today.
A hypothetical form of matter that does not emit light.
It is believed to make up most of the universe's mass.
Its existence is inferred from its gravitational effects.
The galaxy that contains our Solar System.
It has a spiral shape.
Its central supermassive black hole is Sagittarius A*.
The closest major galaxy to the Milky Way.
It is on a collision course with our galaxy.
It is a spiral galaxy.
The system of planets, moons, and other objects orbiting the Sun.
It includes eight major planets.
It is located in the Milky Way galaxy.
A planet that orbits a star outside our Solar System.
The Kepler Space Telescope has discovered thousands of these.
Also known as an extrasolar planet.
The fastest speed in the universe.
Approximately 299,792 kilometers per second.
A fundamental constant of nature.
A star with a very large mass and radius.
Betelgeuse and Rigel are examples.
The largest of all known stars.
The collapsed core of a massive star.
Extremely dense and small in size.
Can be a pulsar or a magnetar.
A system of two stars orbiting a common center of mass.
Most stars in the galaxy are believed to be part of such a system.
Sirius is an example.
An imaginary sphere of infinite radius surrounding Earth.
Used to map the positions of stars and other objects.
The Sun and Moon appear to move along its surface.
A faint, diffuse, and triangular glow seen in the night sky.
Caused by sunlight scattered by interplanetary dust.
It is brightest near the Sun's path on the celestial sphere.
A natural light display in the Earth's sky.
Caused by charged particles from the Sun.
Often called the 'Northern Lights' or 'Southern Lights'.
The outermost layer of the Sun's atmosphere.
Visible during a total solar eclipse.
Extremely hot and less dense than the surface.
A sudden flash of brightness on the Sun's surface.
Releases a large amount of energy.
Can disrupt communication systems on Earth.
An astronomical event where one celestial body passes into the shadow of another.
Can be solar or lunar.
A total one is a spectacular event.
A German astronomer and mathematician.
Formulated three laws of planetary motion.
Worked with Tycho Brahe.
An Italian astronomer and physicist.
Often called the 'father of observational astronomy'.
Improved the telescope and discovered Jupiter's four largest moons.
A Polish astronomer.
Proposed the heliocentric model of the Solar System.
His theory placed the Sun, not the Earth, at the center.
A German-born theoretical physicist.
Developed the theory of general relativity.
His equation E=mc² is famous.
The brightest star in the night sky.
Located in the constellation Canis Major.
Also known as the 'Dog Star'.
A celestial body that orbits the Sun and is large enough to be spherical but not large enough to clear its orbital path.
Pluto and Ceres are examples.
A new category created in 2006.
The time it takes for a celestial body to complete one orbit.
Earth's is approximately 365.25 days.
Also known as a year.
The displacement of spectral lines towards longer wavelengths.
Indicates that a celestial object is moving away from the observer.
Evidence for the expansion of the universe.
The displacement of spectral lines towards shorter wavelengths.
Indicates that a celestial object is moving towards the observer.
The Andromeda galaxy exhibits this.
A graph showing the brightness of a celestial object over time.
Used to study variable stars and exoplanets.
It is a fundamental tool in photometry.
A type of star that pulsates radially, varying in both diameter and temperature.
They have a predictable relationship between their period and luminosity.
Used as 'standard candles' to measure cosmic distances.
An orbital maneuver used to move a spacecraft between two circular orbits.
It uses two engine burns.
The most fuel-efficient way to travel between orbits.
A layer of Earth's atmosphere that is ionized by solar radiation.
It is a good conductor of electricity.
Responsible for radio wave propagation.
The layer of Earth's atmosphere above the mesosphere.
Temperatures can reach thousands of degrees Celsius.
The International Space Station orbits in this layer.
The layers of gases surrounding a planet or other celestial body.
Earth's is composed primarily of nitrogen and oxygen.
Protects the surface from solar radiation.
The arrival of a spacecraft on the surface of the Moon.
Apollo 11 was the first successful human one.
Neil Armstrong's famous 'small step' took place during this.
A NASA program that landed the first humans on the Moon.
Named after the Greek god of the Sun.
Missions were numbered from 1 to 17.
A NASA program that was a stepping stone to Apollo.
Named after the twin constellation.
Focused on perfecting rendezvous and docking techniques.
Two irregular dwarf galaxies orbiting the Milky Way.
Named after a Portuguese explorer.
They are visible in the Southern Hemisphere.
A large group of smaller galaxy clusters and galaxy groups.
The largest known structures in the universe.
The Virgo one contains our Local Group.
The galaxy group that includes the Milky Way and Andromeda.
Contains more than 54 galaxies.
It is part of the Virgo Supercluster.
Occurs when the Moon passes between the Sun and Earth.
The Moon's shadow is cast on Earth.
Can be total, partial, or annular.
Occurs when the Earth passes between the Sun and Moon.
The Earth's shadow is cast on the Moon.
The Moon can appear reddish during a total one.
The point in a planet's orbit where it is closest to the Sun.
For Earth, this occurs in early January.
Derived from Greek words for 'around' and 'Sun'.
The point in a planet's orbit where it is farthest from the Sun.
For Earth, this occurs in early July.
Derived from Greek words for 'away from' and 'Sun'.
A small galaxy that orbits a larger galaxy.
The Magellanic Clouds are examples for the Milky Way.
Subject to tidal forces from its larger companion.
The visible surface of the Sun.
It is the layer that emits most of the Sun's light.
Sunspots are found in this layer.
The second layer of the Sun's atmosphere.
Lies just above the photosphere.
It is only visible during a total solar eclipse as a reddish glow.
A stream of charged particles released from the Sun's upper atmosphere.
Responsible for auroras on Earth.
It flows throughout the Solar System.
The branch of astronomy that deals with the physical properties of celestial objects.
It uses principles of physics and chemistry.
A subfield of astronomy.
The study of the origin, evolution, and fate of the universe.
Involves the Big Bang theory.
A subfield of astronomy.
Natural glass objects formed from terrestrial debris ejected during meteorite impacts.
Found in specific geographical regions on Earth.
Their origin is a subject of debate.
An ancient civilization known for its astronomical observations.
They created the first detailed star charts.
Lived in the area of modern-day Iraq.
A Greek philosopher who argued for a geocentric model.
Believed that the Earth was the center of the universe.
His ideas dominated Western thought for centuries.
A Greco-Roman astronomer who also promoted a geocentric model.
Wrote the 'Almagest', a comprehensive astronomical text.
His model was used until the time of Copernicus.
A well-known constellation representing a hunter.
Visible during winter in the Northern Hemisphere.
Contains the bright stars Betelgeuse and Rigel.
The current North Star.
Located near the North Celestial Pole.
Part of the constellation Ursa Minor.
The points in the sky where the Earth's axis of rotation, if extended, would intersect.
The North one is close to Polaris.
The Southern one has no bright star nearby.
A constellation known as the Great Bear.
Contains the asterism known as the Big Dipper.
Its stars are a guide for finding Polaris.
A constellation known as the Little Bear.
Contains the star Polaris at the end of its 'handle'.
Its asterism is the Little Dipper.
The closest spiral galaxy to the Milky Way.
Visible to the naked eye under dark skies.
It is on a collision course with our galaxy.
The galaxy that contains our Solar System.
A spiral galaxy with a central bar.
Its name comes from its appearance in the night sky.
Large, dark, basaltic plains on the Moon.
Mistaken for seas by early astronomers.
Formed by ancient volcanic eruptions.
The different appearances of the Moon as seen from Earth.
Includes New Moon, First Quarter, Full Moon, and Last Quarter.
Caused by the changing angles of sunlight hitting the Moon.
Bowl-shaped depressions on the surface of a planet or moon.
Caused by the impact of asteroids, comets, or meteoroids.
The Moon is covered in these.
A unit of length equal to the average distance from Earth to the Sun.
Approximately 150 million kilometers.
Abbreviated as AU.
An event that occurs twice each year.
The point where the Sun is farthest north or south of the equator.
Marks the longest and shortest days of the year.
An event that occurs twice each year.
The day when the Sun passes directly over the equator.
Day and night are of roughly equal length everywhere on Earth.
The rise and fall of sea levels.
Caused by the gravitational pull of the Moon and Sun.
Can be high or low.
An orbit that matches Earth's rotation period.
Satellites in this orbit appear stationary in the sky.
Used for communication satellites.
An uncrewed spacecraft sent to explore a distant object.
Voyager 1 and 2 are famous examples.
Can land on a planet or fly by it.
An ancient astronomical instrument.
Used to measure the altitude of celestial objects.
A predecessor to the sextant.
The apparent backward movement of a planet in the sky.
Caused by the relative orbits of Earth and the other planets.
An illusion from our perspective.
A measure of a star's brightness as seen from Earth.
The lower the number, the brighter the star.
Does not account for distance.
A measure of a star's intrinsic brightness.
The brightness of a star if it were located 10 parsecs away.
This is a true measure of luminosity.
The study of the interaction between matter and electromagnetic radiation.
Used to determine the composition of stars.
Analyzes the light from celestial objects.
The astronomical model in which the Earth and planets revolve around the Sun.
Proposed by Copernicus.
The opposite of geocentrism.
The astronomical model in which the Earth is the center of the universe.
Supported by Aristotle and Ptolemy.
The opposite of heliocentrism.
A type of emission nebula consisting of an expanding glowing shell of ionized gas.
Formed by a star shedding its outer layers at the end of its life.
Has nothing to do with planets.
A region of space where stars are born.
Also known as a molecular cloud or a nebula.
The Orion Nebula is a famous example.
A celestial object that is too large to be a planet and too small to be a star.
Fails to sustain hydrogen fusion in its core.
Often called a 'failed star'.
The most energetic and luminous explosions in the universe.
They last from milliseconds to several minutes.
Thought to be caused by supernovae or colliding neutron stars.
A beam of ionized matter ejected from a quasar's core.
Can extend for hundreds of thousands of light-years.
Travels at nearly the speed of light.
High-energy particles that travel through space.
Originate from the Sun and outside the Solar System.
They can affect electronics and astronaut health.
A celestial event in which a number of meteors appear to originate from a single point in the night sky.
Caused by Earth passing through debris left by a comet.
The Perseids are a famous one.
A space rock that survives its passage through the atmosphere and lands on Earth.
Often found in desert areas or Antarctica.
The term for a space rock before it hits the ground is meteoroid.
A small rocky or metallic body in outer space.
Smaller than an asteroid.
Becomes a meteor when it enters the atmosphere.
The mass of a star, usually expressed in units of solar masses.
A key factor in a star's evolution and lifespan.
Our Sun is one solar mass.
A scatter plot of stars showing the relationship between their luminosity and temperature.
Helps classify stars into different types.
The full name is the Hertzsprung-Russell one.
The stage where a star spends most of its life.
During this phase, stars fuse hydrogen into helium in their cores.
The Sun is currently in this stage.
A luminous star of low or intermediate mass in a late phase of stellar evolution.
Our Sun will become one in about 5 billion years.
It is characterized by its large size and reddish color.
A stellar remnant composed mostly of electron-degenerate matter.
The final evolutionary stage of low to medium-mass stars.
It is very dense and slowly cools down over time.
A subatomic particle that is nearly massless and has no electric charge.
Produced in nuclear reactions in stars, including the Sun.
Can pass through ordinary matter almost unimpeded.
The observation that galaxies are moving away from Earth at speeds proportional to their distance.
The cornerstone of the expanding universe theory.
Proposed by Edwin Hubble.
The faint glow of light from the Big Bang.
It fills all of space.
Considered the best evidence for the Big Bang theory.
The largest type of black hole.
Found at the center of most galaxies.
Sagittarius A* is an example.
The supermassive black hole at the center of the Milky Way.
A very strong radio source.
Its mass is about 4 million times that of the Sun.
An instrument used for viewing distant celestial objects.
Can be a reflector or a refractor.
Galileo was one of the first to use one.
A type of optical telescope that uses a lens as its objective.
Galileo's was this type.
It suffers from chromatic aberration.
A type of optical telescope that uses a mirror as its objective.
Invented by Isaac Newton.
Does not suffer from chromatic aberration.
A scientist who studies the physics of the universe.
They study stars, galaxies, and cosmology.
Stephen Hawking was a famous one.
The Russian term for a person trained to travel in a spacecraft.
Yuri Gagarin was the first one.
The American equivalent is an astronaut.
A Soviet pilot and cosmonaut.
The first human to journey into outer space.
His flight was in 1961 aboard Vostok 1.
An American astronaut.
The first person to walk on the Moon.
He said, 'That's one small step for man...'
An American astronaut.
The second person to walk on the Moon.
He was a member of the Apollo 11 mission.
The first mission to land humans on the Moon.
Its crew was Neil Armstrong, Buzz Aldrin, and Michael Collins.
The lunar module was called 'Eagle'.
The first artificial Earth satellite.
Launched by the Soviet Union in 1957.
Its launch marked the beginning of the Space Age.
An image of a small region in the sky captured by the Hubble Space Telescope.
It contains thousands of galaxies.
It reveals the universe's evolution over billions of years.
A NASA space telescope that observes X-rays.
Named after Nobel laureate Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar.
It is used to study black holes and supernovas.
A new infrared space observatory.
It is the successor to the Hubble Space Telescope.
It was launched in 2021.
The largest moon of Saturn.
It is the second-largest moon in the Solar System.
It is the only moon with a dense atmosphere.
One of Jupiter's Galilean moons.
It is believed to have a subsurface ocean of liquid water.
It is a target for future missions to search for life.
The largest moon in the Solar System.
It is one of Jupiter's Galilean moons.
It is larger than the planet Mercury.
Jupiter's second-largest moon.
It has the most heavily cratered surface in the Solar System.
It is the outermost of the Galilean moons.
Jupiter's innermost Galilean moon.
The most volcanically active body in the Solar System.
Its surface is covered in sulfur.
The larger of Mars's two moons.
It is slowly spiraling inward toward Mars.
Its name means 'fear' in Greek.
The smaller of Mars's two moons.
Its name means 'panic' or 'dread' in Greek.
It orbits farther from Mars than Phobos.
The region of space between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter.
It contains most of the Solar System's asteroids.
Ceres is the largest object within it.
A region of the Solar System beyond Neptune.
It contains many small, icy bodies.
Pluto is located within this region.
A hypothetical spherical cloud of icy bodies surrounding the Solar System.
It is the source of long-period comets.
Named after Dutch astronomer Jan Oort.
The solid, central part of a comet.
Often referred to as a 'dirty snowball'.
It is made of rock, dust, and ice.
A structure consisting of hundreds of galaxies bound together by gravity.
The Virgo Cluster is an example.
Larger than a galaxy group.
A galaxy cluster that is part of the Virgo Supercluster.
It is the closest large galaxy cluster to the Local Group.
It contains about 1,300 to 2,000 member galaxies.
A hypothetical form of energy that permeates all of space.
It is believed to be responsible for the accelerating expansion of the universe.
Makes up about 68% of the universe's total energy.
The bending of light from a distant source by a massive object.
Predicted by Albert Einstein's theory of general relativity.
Used to study dark matter and distant galaxies.
A hypothetical tunnel-like shortcut through spacetime.
Could allow for faster-than-light travel.
Predicted by general relativity, but never observed.
The boundary around a black hole.
The point of no return.
Nothing, not even light, can escape from within.
A point of infinite density at the center of a black hole.
Where the laws of physics as we know them break down.
Predicted by general relativity.
Theoretical thermal radiation emitted by a black hole.
Causes black holes to slowly 'evaporate' over time.
Named after physicist Stephen Hawking.
A theoretical physicist and cosmologist.
Known for his work on black holes and the Big Bang.
Wrote 'A Brief History of Time'.
An American astronomer, cosmologist, and science communicator.
Hosted the television series 'Cosmos'.
He was a strong advocate for the Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence (SETI).
An American astrophysicist and science communicator.
Hosted a reboot of the 'Cosmos' television series.
He is the director of the Hayden Planetarium.
A popular science television series.
Originally hosted by Carl Sagan.
Explores the universe and our place in it.
A series of Soviet spacecraft.
The first one carried Yuri Gagarin into space.
It was a single-seat capsule.
The first U.S. satellite program.
Its first successful launch was in 1958.
It followed the launch of the Soviet Sputnik.
An American naval aviator and astronaut.
The first American in space.
He flew on a Mercury mission.
An American Marine Corps aviator, engineer, and astronaut.
The first American to orbit the Earth.
He flew in the Friendship 7 spacecraft.
A modular space station in low Earth orbit.
A collaborative project between several space agencies.
It has been continuously occupied by astronauts since 2000.
The point in an orbit where a satellite is farthest from Earth.
Derived from Greek for 'away from Earth'.
The opposite of perigee.
The point in an orbit where a satellite is closest to Earth.
Derived from Greek for 'around Earth'.
The opposite of apogee.
The time it takes for Earth to rotate once relative to the stars.
Slightly shorter than a solar day.
It is about 23 hours and 56 minutes.
The time it takes for Earth to rotate once relative to the Sun.
It is about 24 hours.
What we commonly refer to as a day.
The closest known star to the Sun.
A red dwarf star.
It is part of a triple star system.
The first Earth-sized exoplanet discovered in the habitable zone of another star.
It orbits a red dwarf star.
Discovered by the Kepler Space Telescope.
The four largest moons of Jupiter.
Discovered by Galileo Galilei.
They are Io, Europa, Ganymede, and Callisto.
A maneuver to transfer a spacecraft from one circular orbit to another.
It is the most fuel-efficient method.
Uses two engine burns to change orbits.
A reusable, low-Earth orbital spacecraft operated by NASA.
Its fleet included Columbia, Challenger, Discovery, Atlantis, and Endeavour.
The program was retired in 2011.
A method of spacecraft propulsion using radiation pressure from stars.
Also known as light sails.
Could be used for interstellar travel.
The region around a star where conditions might allow for liquid water on a planet's surface.
Also known as the 'Goldilocks Zone'.
Earth is located in our Sun's one.
The passage of a planet across the face of its star.
One method used to detect exoplanets.
Venus and Mercury can do this across the face of the Sun.
The second asteroid to be discovered.
It is a very large asteroid, but not the largest.
Named after Pallas Athena.
A major gap in Saturn's rings.
Named after Giovanni Domenico Cassini.
It separates the A and B rings.
A partial ring of material around a planet.
Found around Neptune.
The particles are concentrated in four arcs.
A faint glow in the night sky at the anti-solar point.
The name means 'counterglow' in German.
Caused by the backscattering of sunlight by interplanetary dust.
The apparent path of the Sun in the sky as seen from Earth.
The path is a great circle on the celestial sphere.
The constellations of the Zodiac lie along this path.
The part of the tide caused by the gravitational effects of the Sun and Moon.
It can be accurately predicted.
Differs from a meteorological tide, which is caused by weather.
The apparent wobbling of the Moon when viewed from Earth.
This allows us to see about 59% of the Moon's surface over time.
Not a true physical wobble, but an optical illusion.
The study of the surface and physical features of the Moon.
A branch of planetary science.
Its name is derived from the Greek goddess of the Moon, Selene.
The southernmost point on the Moon's surface.
A region of great interest for future missions.
Permanent shadows here may contain water ice.
The northernmost point on the Moon's surface.
Home to the Peary and Hermite craters.
It receives almost constant sunlight.
A reusable laboratory that flew in the Space Shuttle's cargo bay.
A joint project of the European Space Agency and NASA.
It was used for scientific experiments in space.
A Soviet/Russian space station.
The first continuously inhabited long-term research station in orbit.
It was in operation from 1986 to 2001.
The first series of Soviet space stations.
The name means 'salute' or 'fireworks' in Russian.
Its missions included both military and scientific goals.
A large, roughly spherical region of a galaxy.
Surrounds the main galactic disk.
Contains globular clusters and dark matter.
A spherical collection of stars.
It is tightly bound by gravity and orbits a galactic core.
They are much older than open clusters.
A group of up to a few thousand stars.
They are loosely bound by gravity.
The Pleiades are a famous example.
A constellation named after a mythical king of Ethiopia.
It contains the variable star Delta Cephei.
Located in the northern sky.
A constellation named after a mythical queen of Ethiopia.
Shaped like a 'W' or an 'M'.
Located in the northern sky.
A constellation representing two fish.
One of the twelve constellations of the Zodiac.
Its name is Latin for 'fishes'.
A constellation representing a water-bearer.
One of the twelve constellations of the Zodiac.
Its name is Latin for 'water-bearer'.
A constellation representing a sea-goat.
One of the twelve constellations of the Zodiac.
Its name is Latin for 'horned goat'.
A diffuse nebula located south of Orion's Belt.
One of the brightest nebulae in the night sky.
A famous stellar nursery.
A supernova remnant in the constellation Taurus.
It contains a pulsar at its center.
The supernova that created it was observed in 1054.
A planetary nebula in the constellation Lyra.
It has a distinct ring-like shape.
It is a popular target for amateur astronomers.
A type of galaxy with a smooth, oval shape.
Contains little interstellar gas and dust.
Most of its stars are old.
A type of galaxy with a rotating disk of stars and a central bulge.
The Milky Way and Andromeda are examples.
Characterized by its spiral arms.
A galaxy that does not have a distinct regular shape.
Often the result of a collision or gravitational interaction.
The Magellanic Clouds are examples.
A small galaxy with only a few billion stars.
They are the most common type of galaxy in the universe.
The Magellanic Clouds are examples.
The total amount of energy a star radiates per unit time.
It is the star's intrinsic brightness.
Different from apparent magnitude.
A classification system for stars based on their temperature.
Includes categories like O, B, A, F, G, K, and M.
Our Sun is a G-type star.
A flow of gas and particles from the upper atmosphere of a star.
Similar to the solar wind from our Sun.
It is a key factor in stellar evolution.
A change in velocity over time.
The force of gravity causes this.
It is a vector quantity.
The law that states a planet's orbit is an ellipse with the Sun at one focus.
It describes the shape of planetary orbits.
One of three laws of planetary motion.
The law that states a line from a planet to the Sun sweeps out equal areas in equal amounts of time.
It describes the speed of a planet in its orbit.
A planet moves faster when it is closer to the Sun.
The law that states the square of a planet's orbital period is proportional to the cube of its average distance from the Sun.
It relates a planet's period and distance.
P² = a³.
The constant of proportionality in Hubble's Law.
It relates the recessional velocity of a galaxy to its distance.
Its value is a subject of ongoing research.
A large-scale structure of the universe.
It consists of galaxies, clusters, and superclusters.
It is made of filaments and voids.
A large, thread-like structure of galaxies in the cosmic web.
They are the largest known structures in the universe.
They form the boundaries of large voids.
An empty region of space between filaments of the cosmic web.
Contains few or no galaxies.
These are the largest empty spaces in the universe.
A star that expands and contracts in a rhythmic way.
Its luminosity changes as it pulsates.
Cepheid variables are a type of this.
A pair of stars that orbit each other and periodically eclipse each other.
Their combined brightness appears to decrease when one passes in front of the other.
Algol is a famous example.
A binary star system where the stars are too close to be seen separately.
Their binary nature is revealed by the Doppler shift of their spectral lines.
The lines will alternately shift to red and blue.
The amount of light energy from a star that reaches Earth per unit area.
Also known as 'flux'.
Depends on both the star's luminosity and its distance.
A diagram plotting stars by their temperature and luminosity.
It shows the stages of stellar evolution.
The Sun is on the main sequence in this diagram.
The scientific study of planets, moons, and planetary systems.
Includes the study of their formation and evolution.
A multidisciplinary field.
The branch of astronomy that deals with the motions of celestial objects.
It applies the principles of physics to explain orbits.
Isaac Newton made foundational contributions to this field.
The branch of astronomy that involves measuring the positions and movements of stars.
It provides the fundamental framework for celestial navigation.
Hipparchus is considered the founder of this field.
A subfield of astronomy that studies celestial objects at radio frequencies.
Uses large dish antennas to collect signals.
Karl Jansky is considered the father of this field.
A subfield of astronomy that studies celestial objects using X-ray emissions.
Requires telescopes to be placed in space, as X-rays are blocked by the atmosphere.
The Chandra X-ray Observatory is a famous instrument for this.
A subfield of astronomy that studies celestial objects using infrared radiation.
It can peer through dust clouds to see new stars.
The James Webb Space Telescope is a key instrument for this.
A subfield of astronomy that studies celestial objects using ultraviolet radiation.
Requires telescopes to be placed in space.
Used to study hot stars and distant galaxies.
An asterism in the constellation Orion.
Made of three bright stars in a straight line.
Its stars are Alnitak, Alnilam, and Mintaka.
A red supergiant star in the constellation Orion.
It is one of the largest and most luminous stars.
It is expected to go supernova in the future.
A blue supergiant star in the constellation Orion.
It is the brightest star in the constellation.
It is a key star in the Winter Hexagon.
The brightest star in the night sky.
Part of a binary star system.
It is in the constellation Canis Major.
The brightest star in the constellation Canis Minor.
Part of the Winter Hexagon asterism.
Its name means 'before the dog' in Greek.
The brightest star in the constellation Taurus.
It is a red giant star.
Its name is Arabic for 'the follower'.
The brightest star in the constellation Gemini.
It is an orange giant star.
It is a member of the Winter Hexagon.
The second brightest star in the constellation Gemini.
It is a multiple star system.
Its name is one of the mythical twin brothers.
The brightest star in the constellation Boötes.
A red giant star.
It is the fourth brightest star in the night sky.
A bright star in the constellation Lyra.
It is the second brightest star in the northern celestial hemisphere.
It was once the North Star, and will be again in about 12,000 years.
A bright star in the constellation Aquila.
It is part of the Summer Triangle asterism.
Its name is Arabic for 'the flying eagle'.
A blue-white supergiant star in the constellation Cygnus.
It is part of the Summer Triangle asterism.
Its name is Arabic for 'the tail'.
An asterism of three bright stars in the Northern Hemisphere.
Its stars are Vega, Altair, and Deneb.
It is prominent in the summer sky.
An asterism of six bright stars in the Northern Hemisphere.
Its stars include Sirius, Rigel, Aldebaran, Pollux, Procyon, and Capella.
It is prominent in the winter sky.
A rotating circumstellar disk of dense gas and dust.
Where planets are believed to form.
Also known as a 'proplyd'.
A very young star that is still gathering mass from its parent molecular cloud.
The earliest stage of a star's life.
It is not yet undergoing nuclear fusion.
A star that is fusing hydrogen into helium in its core.
The longest stage of a star's life.
Our Sun is a star of this type.
The process by which dense regions of a molecular cloud collapse.
It leads to the birth of a new star.
Takes place in a stellar nursery.
The structure left behind after a star explodes as a supernova.
The Crab Nebula is an example.
It consists of ejected material from the explosion.
A hypothetical planet in the outer Solar System.
Its existence is inferred from the orbits of other distant objects.
Its existence has not yet been confirmed.
An extrasolar planet with a mass higher than Earth's but substantially below the mass of the ice giants Uranus and Neptune.
There are no examples of this in our Solar System.
It is a type of exoplanet.
A class of exoplanets that are gas giants like Jupiter.
They orbit their star very closely.
Their orbital periods are very short, often a few days.
The potential of a planet to support life.
A key factor is the presence of liquid water.
Also depends on the atmosphere and other conditions.
The study of the origin, evolution, and distribution of life in the universe.
A multidisciplinary field that combines biology, chemistry, and astronomy.
It seeks to answer the question, 'Are we alone?'
The acronym for the Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence.
It uses radio telescopes to listen for signals from other civilizations.
Carl Sagan was a strong advocate for this.
A radio message sent into space from a radio telescope in 1974.
It was aimed at a star cluster called M13.
It contained information about humanity and Earth.
An astronomical instrument that detects radio waves from space.
It can observe objects that are invisible to optical telescopes.
The dish is much larger than for optical telescopes.
A radio astronomy observatory in New Mexico.
It consists of 27 radio antennas arranged in a Y shape.
It is one of the world's premier astronomical radio observatories.
A material that conducts electricity with zero resistance.
Used in some astronomical instruments to increase sensitivity.
Requires extremely cold temperatures to work.
An instrument that separates light into its component wavelengths.
Used in astronomy to study the composition and motion of stars.
It produces a spectrum.
The change in frequency of a wave in relation to an observer.
Used to measure the velocity of stars and galaxies.
Causes a red shift or blue shift.
Hypothetical one-dimensional topological defects in the fabric of spacetime.
Predicted to have been formed in the early universe.
They have not yet been observed.
The energy of empty space.
It is believed to be the cause of dark energy.
It is the lowest possible energy state of a quantum field.
A term added by Albert Einstein to his field equations of general relativity.
Represents the energy density of the vacuum of space.
It is a possible explanation for dark energy.
A hypothetical scenario for the end of the universe.
The universe stops expanding and begins to contract.
It is the opposite of the Big Bang.
A hypothetical scenario for the end of the universe.
The expansion of the universe accelerates until all matter is torn apart.
Driven by dark energy.
A type of universe where spacetime has zero curvature.
It will continue to expand forever, but the rate of expansion will slow down to zero.
Our universe is thought to be this type.
A type of universe where spacetime has positive curvature.
It will eventually stop expanding and collapse back on itself.
This would result in a Big Crunch.
A type of universe where spacetime has negative curvature.
It will expand forever and at an accelerating rate.
This would result in a Big Rip.
A classification scheme for galaxies.
Developed by Edwin Hubble.
It arranges galaxies into a tuning fork-shaped diagram.
A spiral galaxy with a central bar-shaped structure of stars.
The Milky Way is one.
The bar funnels gas toward the center, fueling star formation.
A galaxy intermediate between an elliptical and a spiral galaxy.
It has a central bulge and a disk, but no spiral arms.
It is believed to be a transitional stage.
A type of active galaxy with a compact, bright core.
It has broad emission lines in its spectrum.
Named after astronomer Carl Seyfert.
A very compact quasar associated with a supermassive black hole.
It emits a jet of energy pointing almost directly toward Earth.
The most luminous objects in the universe.
An instrument used to detect high-energy particles from space.
Can be located on the ground, in the atmosphere, or in space.
Used to study the origin of cosmic rays.
An astronomical instrument used to detect neutrinos.
Often located deep underground or under water to shield from other particles.
The IceCube Neutrino Observatory is an example.
A ripple in spacetime caused by accelerating masses.
Predicted by Albert Einstein's theory of general relativity.
The LIGO and Virgo observatories are designed to detect them.
A large-scale physics experiment to detect gravitational waves.
The acronym stands for Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory.
Made the first direct detection of gravitational waves in 2015.
A full or new moon that occurs when the Moon is closest to Earth.
It appears slightly larger and brighter than a normal full moon.
It is a perigee syzygy.
The third full moon in a season with four full moons.
Also refers to the second full moon in a calendar month.
This is not a color-related term.
The phenomenon where a satellite's rotation period matches its orbital period.
The Moon is tidally locked with Earth.
As a result, we always see the same side of the Moon.
The hemisphere of the Moon that is permanently turned away from Earth.
Often incorrectly called the 'dark side'.
It was first photographed by the Soviet probe Luna 3.
The light-colored, heavily cratered, mountainous regions on the Moon.
They are older than the lunar maria.
They are anorthositic in composition.
A collision of a large space rock with a planet or moon.
It can cause large craters and mass extinctions.
The Chicxulub one is linked to the end of the dinosaurs.
A powerful explosion over Siberia in 1908.
Believed to have been caused by a meteoroid exploding in the atmosphere.
It flattened millions of trees over a wide area.
A military installation in Colorado.
It houses the North American Aerospace Defense Command (NORAD).
Its primary purpose is to monitor for missile and air threats.
The first crewed mission to orbit the Moon.
Its crew read from the book of Genesis on Christmas Eve.
Frank Borman, James Lovell, and William Anders were the crew.
A crewed mission to the Moon that suffered an in-flight explosion.
The crew had to return to Earth without landing.
Their famous phrase was 'Houston, we've had a problem'.
The first United States space station.
Launched in 1973.
Its missions focused on scientific research and solar observations.
A public planetarium in New York City.
Part of the American Museum of Natural History.
Neil deGrasse Tyson is the director of this.
A small, rocky body that may have formed a planet.
Formed in the early Solar System.
They are the building blocks of planets.
A pseudoscience that claims to foretell future events by interpreting the positions of stars and planets.
It is not a part of science.
It uses the signs of the Zodiac.
A second-century book on astronomy.
Written by Ptolemy.
It was the standard reference for astronomers for over a thousand years.
A measure of how much an orbit deviates from a perfect circle.
An eccentricity of zero means a perfectly circular orbit.
The orbits of most planets in our Solar System have low eccentricity.
The angle between a celestial object's orbit and a reference plane.
For planets in the Solar System, the reference plane is the ecliptic.
Pluto has a high orbital one.
Any minor planet in the Solar System that orbits the Sun at a greater distance than Neptune.
Pluto is one of these.
The Kuiper Belt is home to many of these objects.
A layer of loose, fragmented rock and dust on the Moon's surface.
It is caused by meteorite impacts.
The Apollo astronauts collected samples of this.
A planet that is composed primarily of silicate rocks or metals.
Mercury, Venus, Earth, and Mars are examples.
Also known as 'rocky planets'.
